content.title: Adding Algebraic Fractions
content.content: Just like fractions involving numbers, fractions involving algebra can be added by writing them with a common denominator.

content.title: Partial Fractions Introduction
content.content: When we study calculus later in the course, we are more likely to want to reverse this process. We need to decompose a function such as (7x + 1)/(x^2 + x - 6) into the sum of partial fractions 3/(x - 2) + 4/(x + 3) so it can be integrated.

content.title: Decomposing into Partial Fractions
steps: Step 2: Write a sum of partial fractions with the factors as denominators and unknown numerators
Step 3: Multiply both sides by the denominator
Step 4: Find the unknown numerators by substituting the zeros of the denominators

problems.description: Determine whether each of the following statements is true or false. Provide explanations for your answers

statements.content: If a graph on the Cartesian plane is the graph of a function, then every vertical line passes through exactly one point
A graph on the Cartesian plane is the graph of a function if and only if every vertical line passes through at most one point
If no horizontal line passes through more than one point on a given graph on the coordinate plane, then the graph is the graph of a function that has an inverse
If no horizontal line passes through more than one point of the graph of a function, then the function has an inverse
The graph of y = f(x + 2) is the graph of y = f(x) shifted two units to the left
The graph of y = f(3x) + 4 is the result of stretching the graph of y = f(x) vertically by a factor of 3, then shifting the result 4 units up

content.title: Opening Problem - Exponential Functions Chapter
content.content: At an antiques fair, Bernard purchases a clock for 500 pounds and a vase for 400 pounds. The clock increases in value by 5% each year, and the vase increases in value by 7% each year.

things_to_think_about.content: What is the value of each item 1 year after purchase?
Can you write a formula for the value of each item t years after purchase?
Which item is more valuable 15 years after purchase?
How can we determine when the items are equal in value?

content.title: Review of Exponents
content.content: We have seen previously how exponents are used to indicate when a number is raised to a power.

rules: For a positive integer exponent, the exponent tells us how many of the base are multiplied together
Any non-zero base to the power 0 is defined as 1, to give consistency to the exponent laws
For a negative integer exponent, we take the reciprocal of the corresponding positive integer power

content.title: Rational Exponents
content.content: The laws of exponents used previously can also be applied to rational exponents, or exponents in Q.
derivation: For any a > 0, notice that a^(1/2) x a^(1/2) = a^(1/2 + 1/2) = a^1 = a {exponent laws}
and sqrt(a) x sqrt(a) = a also
and cbrt(a) x cbrt(a) x cbrt(a) = a also
By direct comparison, we conclude that a^(1/2) = sqrt(a) and a^(1/3) = cbrt(a)
content.general_rule: In general, a^(1/n) = n-th root of a, where n-th root reads 'the nth root of a' for n in Z+

content.content: We can now determine that n-th root of a^m = (a^m)^(1/n) = a^(m/n)
content.formula: a^(m/n) = n-th root of a^m for a > 0, n in Z+, m in Z
